Full gladsome was my heart ere while to tell</br>How proud Ambition owned superior Love;</br>For ah!  too oft his sterner power could quell</br>The mild affections which more gently move,</br>And rather silent fled than with him strove:</br>For Love content and tranquil saw with dread</br>The busy scenes Ambition's schemes approve,</br>And, by the hand of Peace obscurely led,</br>From pride of public life disgusted ever fled.

There are who know not the delicious charm</br>Of sympathising hearts; let such employ</br>Their active minds; the trumpet's loud alarm</br>Shall yield them hope of honourable joy,</br>And courts may lure them with each splendid toy:</br>But ne'er may vanity or thirst of fame</br>The dearer bliss of loving life destroy!</br>Oh!  blind to man's chief good who Love disclaim,</br>And barter pure delight for glory's empty name!

Blest Psyche!  thou hast 'scaped the tyrants power!</br>Thy gentle heart shall never know the pain</br>Which tortures pride in his most prosperous hour:</br>Yet dangers still unsung for thee remain;</br>Nor must thou unmolested hope to gain</br>Immortal beauty's never failing spring;</br>Oh!  no — nor yet tranquillity attain:</br>But though thy heart the pangs of doubt may sting,</br>Thy faithful knight shall yet thy steps in safety bring.

Warned by late peril now she scarcely dares</br>Quit for one moment his protecting eye:</br>Sure in his sight, her soul of nought despairs,</br>And nought looks dreadful when that arm is nigh</br>On which her hopes with confidence rely;</br>By his advice their constant course they bend,</br>He points where hidden danger they should fly,</br>On him securely, as her heaven-sent friend,</br>She bids her grateful heart contentedly depend.

Oh!  who the exquisite delight can tell,</br>The joy which mutual confidence imparts!</br>Or who can paint the charm unspeakable</br>Which links in tender bands two faithful hearts?</br>In vain assailed by fortune's envious darts,</br>Their mitigated woes are sweetly shared,</br>And doubled joy reluctantly departs:</br>Let but the sympathising heart be spared,</br>What sorrow seems not light, what peril is not dared?

Oh!  never may suspicion's gloomy sky</br>Chill the sweet glow of fondly trusting love!</br>Nor ever may he feel the scowling eye</br>Of dark distrust his confidence reprove!</br>In pleasing error may I rather rove,</br>With blind reliance on the hand so dear,</br>Than let cold prudence from my eyes remove</br>Those sweet delusions, where nor doubt nor fear</br>Nor foul disloyalty nor cruel change appear.

The noble mind is ever prone to trust;</br>Yet love with fond anxiety is joined;</br>And timid tenderness is oft unjust;</br>The coldness which it dreads too prompt to find,</br>And torture the too susceptible mind.</br>Hence rose the gloom which oft o'er Psyche stole</br>Lest he she loved, unmindful or unkind,</br>Should careless slight affection's soft control,</br>Or she long absent lose her influence o'er his soul.

'Twas evening, and the shades which sudden fell</br>Seemed to forebode a dark unlovely night;</br>The sighing wood-nymphs from their caves foretel</br>The storm which soon their quiet shall affright:</br>Nor cheering star nor moon appears in sight,</br>Nor taper twinkles through the rustling leaves</br>And sheds afar its hospitable light:</br>But hark!  a dismal sound the ear receives,</br>And through the obscuring gloom the eye strange forms perceives.

It was a helpless female who exclaimed,</br>Whose blind and aged form an ass sustained:</br>Misshaped and timorous, of light ashamed,</br>In darksome woods her hard-earned food she gained,</br>And her voracious appetite maintained,</br>Though all devouring, yet unsatisfied;</br>Nor aught of hard digestion she disdained,</br>Whate'er was offered greedily she tried,</br>And meanly served, as slave, whoever food supplied.

A cruel monster now her steps pursued,</br>Well known of yore and named the Blatant Beast;</br>And soon he seized his prey with grasp so rude,</br>So fiercely on her feeble body prest,</br>That had the courteous knight not soon released</br>Her unresisting limbs from violence,</br>She must have sunk by his rough jaws opprest:</br>The spiteful beast, enraged at the defence,</br>Now turned upon the knight with foaming vehemence.

But, when his fury felt the couched spear,</br>On Psyche's unarmed form he bellowing flew;</br>'Twas there alone the knight his rage could fear;</br>Swifter than thought his flaming sword he drew,</br>And from his hand the doubtful javelin threw</br>Lest erring it might wound the trembling fair:</br>Eager the cruel monster to subdue</br>He scorned to use his shield's protecting care,</br>And rashly left his side in part exposed and bare.

Sharp were the wounds of his avenging steel,</br>Which forced the roaring beast to quit the field:</br>Yet ere he fled, the knight unused to feel</br>The power of any foe, or e'er to yield</br>To any arm which sword or spear could wield,</br>Perceived the venom of his tooth impure;</br>But, with indignant silence, unrevealed</br>The pain he bore, while through the gloom obscure</br>The beast, in vain pursued, urged on his flight secure.

And now the hag, delivered from her fear,</br>Her grateful thanks upon the knight bestowed,</br>And, as they onward went, in Psyche's ear</br>Her tongue with many a horrid tale o'erflowed,</br>Which warned her to forsake that venturous road,</br>And seek protection in the neighbouring grove;</br>Where dwelt a prudent dame, who oft bestowed</br>Her sage advice, when pilgrims doomed to rove,</br>Benighted there, had else with lurking dangers strove.

The knight now softly bade his charge beware,</br>Nor trust Credulity whom well he knew:</br>Yet he himself, harassed with pain and care,</br>And heedful of the storm which fiercer grew,</br>Yielded, a path more sheltered to pursue:</br>Now soon entangled in a gloomy maze</br>Psyche no longer has her knight in view,</br>Nor sees his page's star-crowned helmet blaze;</br>Close at her side alone the hag loquacious stays.

Fearful she stops, and calls aloud in vain,</br>The storm-roused woods roar only in reply;</br>Anxious her loved protector to regain</br>She trembling listens to Credulity,</br>Who points where they a glimmering light may spy;</br>Which, through the shade of intervening trees</br>And all the misty blackness of the sky,</br>Casting a weak and dubious ray she sees,</br>And fain by this would seek her terrors to appease.

Yet hoping that, allured by that same light</br>Which singly seemed through all the gloom to shine,</br>She there at last might meet her wandering knight,</br>Thither her footsteps doubtingly incline</br>As best the uncertain path they could divine,</br>All tangled as it wound through brake and briar:</br>While to affright her soul at once combine</br>A thousand shapeless forms of terror dire,</br>Here shrieks the ill-omened bird, there glares the meteor's fire.

In the deep centre of the mazy wood,</br>With matted ivy and wild vine o'ergrown,</br>A Gothic castle solitary stood,</br>With massive walls built firm of murky stone;</br>Long had Credulity its mistress known,</br>Meagre her form and tawny was her hue,</br>Unsociably she lived, unloved, alone,</br>No cheerful prospects gladdened e'er her view,</br>And her pale hollow eyes oblique their glances threw.

Now had they reached the sad and dreary bower</br>Where dark Disfida held her gloomy state:</br>The grated casements strong with iron power,</br>The huge port-cullis creaking o'er the gate,</br>The surly guards that round the draw-bridge wait,</br>Chill Psyche's heart with sad foreboding fears;</br>Nor ever had she felt so desolate</br>As when at length her guide the porter hears,</br>And at the well known call reluctantly appears.

In hall half lighted with uncertain rays,</br>Such as expiring tapers transient shed,</br>The gloomy princess sat, no social blaze</br>The unkindled hearth supplied, no table spread</br>Cheered the lone guest who weetless wandered,</br>But melancholy silence reigned around,</br>While on her arm she leaned her pensive head,</br>And anxious watched, as sullenly she frowned,</br>Of distant whispers low to catch the doubtful sound.

Startled to hear an unaccustomed noise</br>Sudden she rose, and on the intruders bent</br>Her prying eye askance; but soon the voice</br>Of her old slave appeased her discontent,</br>And a half welcome to her guests she lent:</br>Her frequent questions satisfied at last,</br>Through all the neighbouring woods her scouts she sent</br>To seek the knight, while Psyche's tears flowed fast,</br>And all the live-long night in anxious woe she past.

The sullen bell had told the midnight hour,</br>And sleep had laid the busy world to rest,</br>All but the watchful lady of that bower</br>And wretched Psyche:  her distracted breast</br>The agony of sad suspense opprest,</br>Now to the casement eagerly she flies,</br>And now the wished-for voice her fancy blest:</br>Alas!  the screaming night-bird only cries;</br>Only the drear obscure there meets her straining eyes.

Has thy heart sickened with deferred hope?</br>Or felt the impatient anguish of suspense?</br>Or hast thou tasted of the bitter cup</br>Which disappointment's withered hands dispense?</br>Thou knowest the poison which o'erflowed from hence</br>O'er Psyche's tedious, miserable hours.</br>The unheeded notes of plaintive Innocence</br>No longer sooth her soul with wonted powers,</br>While false Disfida's tales her listening ear devours.

Of rapid torrents and deep marshy fens,</br>Of ambushed foes and unseen pits they tell,</br>Of ruffians rushing from their secret dens,</br>Of foul magicians and of wizard spell,</br>The poisoned lance and net invisible;</br>While Psyche shuddering sees her knight betrayed</br>Into the snares of some enchanter fell,</br>Beholds him bleeding in the treacherous shade,</br>Or hears his dying voice implore in vain for aid.

At length the cruel messengers return,</br>Their trampling steeds sound welcome in her ear;</br>Her rapid feet the ground impatient spurn,</br>As eagerly she flies their news to hear.</br>Alas!  they bring no tidings which may cheer</br>Her sorrowing soul opprest, disconsolate!</br>"Dismiss," they cry, "each idly timid fear!</br>No dangers now thy faithless knight await,</br>Lured by a wanton fair to bowers of peaceful state.

"We saw him blithely follow where she led,</br>And urged him to return to thee in vain:</br>Some other knight, insultingly he said,</br>Thy charms might soon for thy protection gain,</br>If still resolved to tread with weary pain</br>The tedious road to that uncertain land;</br>But he should there contentedly remain;</br>No other bliss could now his heart demand</br>Than that new lady's love and kindly proffered hand."

A while she stood in silent wonder lost,</br>And scarce believes the strange abandonment;</br>No fears like this her heart had ever crost,</br>Nor could she think his mind so lightly bent</br>Could swerve so quickly from its first intent;</br>Till sudden bursting forth in angry mood</br>Disfida gave her indignation vent,</br>"Ah, well I know," she cried, "that wicked brood</br>Whose cursed ensnaring arts in vain my cares withstood,

"Vile Varia's fickle and inconstant train,</br>Perpetual torments of my harassed days:</br>Their nightly thefts my fruits, my flowers sustain,</br>Their wanton goats o'er all my vineyards graze,</br>My corn lies scattered, and my fences blaze,</br>My friends, my followers they basely lure;</br>I know their mischievous detested ways!</br>My castle vainly have I built so sure</br>While from their treacherous wiles my life is insecure.

"But I will lead thee to the glittering sands,</br>Where shines their hollow many-coloured fane:</br>There, as the circling group fantastic stands,</br>Thy truant knight perhaps thou mayst regain</br>From the light arts of that seductive train."</br>She paused-but Psyche spoke not in reply;</br>Her noble heart, which swelled with deep disdain,</br>Forbad the utterance of a single sigh,</br>And shamed the indignant tear which started to her eye.

At length with firm, but gentle dignity</br>And cold averted eye she thus replies:</br>"No!  let him go:  nor power nor wish have I</br>His conduct to control.  Let this suffice;</br>Before my path a surer guardian flies,</br>By whose direction onward I proceed</br>Soon as the morn's first light shall clear the skies."</br>She ceased, then languishing her griefs to feed,</br>Her cold dark chamber sought from observation freed.

'Twas there regret indulged the bitter tear;</br>She feels herself forsaken and alone:</br>"Behold," she cries, "fulfilled is every fear,</br>Oh!  wretched Psyche, now indeed undone!</br>Thy love's protecting care no more is shown,</br>He bids his servant leave thee to thy fate,</br>Nor longer will the hopeless wanderer own:</br>Some fairer, nobler spouse, some worthier mate,</br>At length by Venus given shall share his heavenly state.

"Oh!  most adored!  Oh!  most regretted love!</br>Oh!  joys that never must again be mine,</br>And thou lost hope, farewell! — vainly I rove,</br>For never shall I reach that land divine,</br>Nor ever shall thy beams celestial shine</br>Again upon my sad unheeded way!</br>Oh!  let me here with life my woes resign,</br>Or in this gloomy den for ever stay,</br>And shun the scornful world, nor see detested day."

"But no!  those scenes are hateful to mine eyes,</br>And all who spoke or witnessed my disgrace;</br>My soul with horror from this dwelling flies</br>And seeks some tranquil, solitary place</br>Where grief may finish life's unhappy race!"</br>So past she the long night, and soon as morn</br>Had first begun to show his cheerful face,</br>Her couch, which care had strewn with every thorn,</br>With heavy heart she left, disquieted, forlorn.

Not thus Disfida suffered her to part,</br>But urged her there in safety to remain,</br>Repeating oft to her foreboding heart</br>That fairy land she never could attain:</br>But when she saw dissuasion was in vain,</br>And Psyche bent her journey to pursue,</br>With angry brow she called a trusty train</br>And bade them keep the imprudent fair in view,</br>And guard her dangerous path with strict observance true.

In vain their proffered service she declines,</br>And dreads the convoy of the scowling band;</br>Their hateful presence with her loss combines,</br>She feels betrayed to the destroyer's hand,</br>And trembling wanders o'er the dreary land;</br>While as she seeks to escape Disfida's power,</br>Her efforts still the officious guards withstand,</br>Led in vain circles many a tedious hour,</br>Undistanced still she sees the gloomy turrets lower.

Till wearied with her fruitless way, at length</br>Upon the ground her fainting limbs she threw;</br>No wish remained to aid exhausted strength,</br>The mazy path she cared not to pursue,</br>Since unavailing was the task she knew:</br>Her murmuring guards to seek for food prepare,</br>Yet mindful of their charge, still keep in view</br>The drooping victim of their cruel care,</br>Who sees the day decline in terror and despair.

Hark!  a low hollow groan she seems to hear</br>Repeated oft; wondering she looks around:</br>It seemed to issue from some cavern near,</br>Or low hut hidden by the rising ground;</br>For, though it seemed the melancholy sound</br>Of human voice, no human form was nigh;</br>Her eye no human habitation found,</br>But as she listening gazed attentively,</br>Her shuddering ears received the deep and long drawn sigh.

The guard who nearest stood now whispering said,</br>"If aught of doubt remain within thy mind,</br>Or wish to know why thus thou wert betrayed,</br>Or what strange cause thy faithless knight inclined</br>To leave the charge he with such scorn resigned,</br>Each curious thought thou now mayst satisfy,</br>Since here the entrance of a cave we find,</br>Where dwells, deep hid from day's too garish eye,</br>A sage whose magic skill can solve each mystery."

He staid not her reply, but urged her on</br>Reluctant to the dark and dreary cave;</br>No beam of cheerful Heaven had ever shone</br>In the recesses of that gloomy grave,</br>Where screaming owls their daily dwelling crave.</br>One sickly lamp the wretched master shewed;</br>Devouring fiend!  Who now the prey shall save</br>From his fell gripe, whose hands in blood imbrued,</br>In his own bosom seek his lacerated food?

On the damp ground he sits in sullen woe,</br>But wildly rolls around his frenzied eye,</br>And gnaws his withered lips, which still o'erflow</br>With bitter gall; in foul disorder lie</br>His black and matted locks; anxiety</br>Sits on his wrinkled brow and sallow cheek;</br>The wasted form, the deep-drawn, frequent sigh,</br>Some slow consuming malady bespeak,</br>But medicinal skill the cause in vain shall seek.

"Behold," the treacherous guard exclaimed, "behold,</br>At length Disfida sends thy promised bride!</br>Let her, deserted by her knight, be told</br>What peerless lady lured him from her side;</br>Thy cares her future safety must provide."</br>Smiling maliciously as thus he spoke,</br>He seemed her helpless anguish to deride;</br>Then swiftly rushing from the den he broke,</br>Ere from the sudden shock astonished she awoke.

She too had fled; but when the wretch escaped</br>He closed the cavern's mouth with cruel care;</br>And now the monster placed his form mis-shaped</br>To bar the passage of the affrighted fair:</br>Her spirits die, she breathes polluted air,</br>And vaporous visions swim before her sight:</br>His magic skill the sorcerer bids her share,</br>And lo!  as in a glass, she sees her knight</br>In bower remembered well, the bower of loose Delight.

But oh!  what words her feelings can impart!</br>Feelings to hateful envy near allied!</br>While on her knight her anxious glances dart:</br>His plumed helmet, lo!  he lays aside;</br>His face with torturing agony she spied,</br>Yet cannot from the sight her eyes remove;</br>No mortal knight she sees had aid supplied,</br>No mortal knight in her defence had strove;</br>'Twas Love!  'twas Love himself, her own adored Love.

Poured in soft dalliance at a lady's feet,</br>In fondest rapture he appeared to lie,</br>While her fair neck with inclination sweet</br>Bent o'er his graceful form her melting eye,</br>Which his looked up to meet in ecstasy.</br>Their words she heard not; words had ne'er exprest,</br>What well her sickening fancy could supply,</br>All that their silent eloquence confest,</br>As breathed the sigh of fire from each impassioned breast.

While thus she gazed, her quivering lips turn pale;</br>Contending passions rage within her breast,</br>Nor ever had she known such bitter bale,</br>Or felt by such fierce agony opprest.</br>Oft had her gentle heart been sore distrest,</br>But meekness ever has a lenient power</br>From anguish half his keenest darts to wrest;</br>Meekness for her had softened sorrow's hour,</br>Those furious fiends subdued which boisterous souls devour.

For there are hearts that, like some sheltered lake,</br>Ne'er swell with rage, nor foam with violence;</br>Though its sweet placid calm the tempests shake,</br>Yet will it ne'er with furious impotence</br>Dash its rude waves against the rocky fence,</br>Which nature placed the limits of its reign:</br>Thrice blest!  who feel the peace which flows from hence,</br>Whom meek-eyed gentleness can thus restrain;</br>Whate'er the storms of fate, with her let none complain!

That mild associate Psyche now deserts,</br>Unlovely passions agitate her soul,</br>The vile magician all his art exerts,</br>And triumphs to behold his proud control:</br>Changed to a serpent's hideous form, he stole</br>O'er her fair breast to suck her vital blood;</br>His poisonous involutions round her roll:</br>Already is his forked tongue imbrued</br>Warm in the stream of life, her heart's pure purple flood.

Thus wretchedly she falls Geloso's prey!</br>But her, once more, unhoped for aid shall save!</br>Admitted shines the clear blue light of day</br>Upon the horrors of that gloomy grave;</br>Her knight's soft voice resounds through all the cave,</br>The affrighted serpent quits his deadly hold,</br>Nor dares the vengeance of his arm to brave,</br>Shrunk to a spider's form, while many a fold</br>Of self-spun web obscene the sorcerer vile enrolled.

Scarce had the star of his attendant youth</br>Blazed through the cavern and proclaimed the knight,</br>When all those spells and visions of untruth,</br>Bred in dark Erebus and nursed in night,</br>Dissolving vanished into vapour light;</br>While Psyche, quite exhausted by her pains,</br>And hardly trusting her astonished sight,</br>Now faint and speechless in his arms remains,</br>Nor memory of the past, nor present sense retains.

Borne from the cavern, and to life restored,</br>Her opening eyes behold her knight once more,</br>She sees whom lost with anguish she deplored;</br>Yet a half-feigned resentment still she bore,</br>Nor sign of joy her face averted wore,</br>Though joy unuttered panted at her heart;</br>In sullen silence much she pondered o'er</br>What from her side induced him to depart,</br>And all she since had seen by aid of magic art.

Was it then all a false deluding dream</br>That wore the semblance of celestial Love?</br>On this her wavering thoughts bewildered seem</br>At length to rest; yet onward as they move,</br>Though much his tender cares her doubts reprove,</br>And though she longs to hear, and pardon all,</br>Silence she still preserves:  awhile he strove</br>Her free and cheerful spirits to recall,</br>But found the task was vain; his words unnoticed fall.

Now in his turn offended and surprised,</br>The knight in silence from her side withdrew;</br>With pain she marked it, but her pain disguised,</br>And heedless seemed her journey to pursue,</br>Nor backward deigned to turn one anxious view</br>As oft she wished; till mindful of his lord,</br>Constance alarmed affectionately flew,</br>Eager to see their mutual peace restored,</br>And blamed her cold reserve in many a soft breathed word.

"O Psyche!  wound not thus thy faithful knight,</br>Who fondly sought thee many an anxious hour,</br>Though bleeding yet from that inglorious fight,</br>Where thou wert rescued from the savage power</br>Of that fell beast who would thy charms devour:</br>Still faint with wounds, he ceased not to pursue</br>Thy heedless course:  let not displeasure lower</br>Thus on thy brow:  think not his heart untrue!</br>Think not that e'er from thee he willingly withdrew!"

With self-reproach and sweet returning trust,</br>While yet he spoke, her generous heart replies,</br>Soft melting pity bids her now be just</br>And own the error which deceived her eyes;</br>Her little pride she longs to sacrifice,</br>And ask forgiveness of her suffering knight;</br>Her suffering knight, alas!  no more she spies,</br>He has withdrawn offended from her sight,</br>Nor can that gentle voice now hope to stay his flight.

Struggling no more her sorrows to restrain,</br>Her streaming eyes look round with anxious fear;</br>Nor are those tender showers now shed in vain,</br>Her soft lamenting voice has reached his ear,</br>Where latent he had marked each precious tear;</br>Sudden as thought behold him at her feet!</br>Oh!  reconciling moment!  charm most dear!</br>What feeling heart thy pleasures would repeat,</br>Or wish thy dearly purchased bliss, however sweet?

The smiles of joy which swell her glowing cheek,</br>And o'er her parting lips divinely play,</br>Returning pleasure eloquently speak,</br>Forgetful of the tears which lingering stay,</br>(Like sparkling dew drops in a sunny day)</br>Unheeded tenants of rejoicing eyes;</br>His wounds her tender care can well repay:</br>There grateful kindness breathes her balmy sighs,</br>Beneath her lenient hand how swiftly suffering flies!

Freed from the mazes of Disfida's groves,</br>The opening landscape brightens to their view;</br>Psyche, with strength revived, now onward moves</br>In cheerful hope, with courage to renew</br>Repeated toils, and perils to pursue:</br>Thus when some tender plant neglected pines,</br>Shed o'er its pendent head the kindly dew,</br>How soon refreshed its vivid lustre shines!</br>Once more the leaf expands, the drooping tendril twines.

Thus cheered, the knight intreats her to impart</br>The dangers which her way had since befel,</br>Her timid lips refuse to speak the art</br>Which clothed him in a form she loved so well:</br>That she had thought him Love, she blushed to tell!</br>Confused she stopt; a gentle pause ensued;</br>What chance had brought him to the demon's cell</br>She then enquires; what course he had pursued,</br>And who his steps had led throughout the mazy wood.

Sooth he had much to say, though modest shame</br>His gallant deeds forbade him to declare;</br>For while through those bewildering woods he came,</br>Assisted by his page's active care,</br>He had detected Varia's wily snare,</br>And forced her wanton retinue to flee.</br>With like disgrace, malignant in despair,</br>Disfida's slaves their plots defeated see,</br>Their feeble malice scorned, their destined victims free.

But he had marked the traces of their feet,</br>And found the path which to the cavern led:</br>Whence now, rejoicing in reunion sweet,</br>Their way together cheerfully they tread,</br>Exempt awhile from danger and from dread;</br>While Psyche's heart, with confidence more bold,</br>Full oft the hour of rapture pictured,</br>When those celestial charms she should behold,</br>And feel the arms of Love once more his bride enfold.
